Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation - Reducing Seismic Vulnerability

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The George E. Brown, Jr. Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation (NEES) is an NSF funded distributed laboratory aimed at reducing the vulnerability of the nation's infrastructure to the damaging effects of large earthquakes, tsunamis, and other large scale disasters. The NEES collaboratory includes 14 large-scale experimental research facilities that house state-of-the-art equipment including shake tables, tsunami wave basins, field testing facilities, large-scale structural laboratories, and geotechnical centrifuges. The facilities are linked by an advanced IT cyberinfrastructure, allowing real time collaboration among laboratories and researchers doing testing. This interlinked system of laboratories enables researchers to study the response of engineered systems at a scale and complexity not possible before. This collaborative research has significantly increased our knowledge of vulnerable systems, accelerating the rate at which research discoveries are made and integrated into technologies, design rules, and knowledge for use by engineering practitioners.

This three-year REU Site program will provide a unique opportunity for eleven undergraduate students to be involved in NEES projects and be engaged in utilizing NEES advanced cyberinfrastructure. The REU students will have a variety of opportunities to work with world class researchers and their graduate students in the areas of structures, geotechnical engineering and tsunami mitigation. Those students interested in information technology development will work with experts to develop new tools that can become part of the cyberinfrastructure network supporting the NEES community. Students will synthesize research outcomes into learning resources that can be shared on the cyberinfrastructure being developed by the NEEScomm IT team. REU participants will also perform research at several laboratory nodes around the country, and will collaborate between the cohorts using 3D virtual world technologies.

In addition to the research projects, students will be engaged in a series of enrichment activities that will help them become more confident as researchers, including an orientation meeting which will help foster community building among all the students, provide a technical program that introduces the basics of earthquake engineering and NEES to the students, provide training in communication and effective library research, and provide information about graduate school. Team building activities will also be an important program element to help develop the cohort. REU students will participate in the Tsunami Shelter Challenge, developed as an education and outreach activity at NEES@oregonstate. Participants will go on at least one field trip which they will be required to report on in the virtual environment through a multimedia presentation.

At the end of the 10-week REU program another NEES facility site, will host the Young Researcher Symposium. This program will be two days, and the main focus will be student presentations of their final research. The program will include a facility tour, short technical program with a keynote speaker, the presentation of student research, and a final dinner with awards for best presentation. Students will prepare for this event through a Virtual Research Symposium with students from several other NSF REU programs using a 3D virtual world.

What are the broader impacts of the proposed activity?
The Principal Investigators plan to recruit a diverse pool of students to engage with the NEEScom network of researchers and affiliates. They are committed to attracting underrepresented students and aim to build diversity within the NEES program, the earthquake engineering community, and the engineering community as a whole by recruiting 50% of its participants from underrepresented groups in STEM careers, including women, minorities and persons with disabilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Operated through the George E. Brown, Jr. Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation (NEES), the research experience for undergraduates (REU) program entitled NEESreu: Reducing Seismic Vulnerability has provided students the opportunity to participate in large scale experimental research and learn to collaborate in a network of other young scholars.  NEES, funded by the National Science Foundation, is a distributed laboratory supporting research aimed at reducing the vulnerability of the nation’s infrastructure to the damaging effects of large earthquakes, tsunamis, and other large scale natural disasters. The NEES collaboratory (nees.org) includes 14 large-scale experimental research facilities that house state-of-the-art equipment including shake tables, tsunami wave basins, field testing facilities, large-scale structural laboratories, and geotechnical centrifuges (Figure1). The facilities are linked by an advanced IT cyberinfrastructure, allowing real time collaboration among laboratories and researchers during testing. This interlinked system of laboratories enables researchers to study the response of engineered systems at a scale and complexity not possible before.

A main goal of the NEESreu program is to influence the future of earthquake engineering with special attention to training and mentoring a diverse, professionally prepared workforce, and to attract undergraduate and underrepresented students into STEM careers. Students gain an understanding of the global impact of earthquake engineering; confidence in use of Web 2.0 technologies; and enthusiasm for research that translates into a desire to pursue postgraduate education; and develop a network of peers that lasts beyond the REU. Earthquake engineering is rarely taught as an undergraduate topic.  Therefore, students benefit from learning many theoretical concepts  that they often do not encounter until graduate school or working in industry.

NEES research spans a wide range of topics from tsunami hazard mitigation to soil-structure interaction to new sensor technology. NEES research is large scale, for example testing a full-scale 5-story building on a shake table. These projects engage teams of 5 to 20 researchers and support staff over periods of 12 to 36 months to build, test, and analze the physical models that require thousands of sensors to collect the data. By contributing to such large-scale projects REU students become aware of the physical scale and complexity of earthquake engineering research.  Students have collaborated with mentors to build and instrument specimens, perform computer simulations, perform physical experiments (Figure 2), analyze data and communicate their experiences through poster presentations and project papers. In addition to engaging in cutting edge research, students experienced a wealth of local and virtual professional development activities centered on the theme Reducing Seismic Vulnerability through Collaboration (Figure 3) such as field trips and interaction with practicing professionals.

Typically 5 to 7 of the 14 NEES research laboratories support small REU cohorts ranging from 2 to 7 students each summer. Thus students are distributed across the country from California to New York. From 2010 to 2013 the NSF-funded NEESreu site supported 11 students per year, but was able to serve 92 students by folding in undergraduate researchers from other NEES projects. This has benefitted the students by creating larger undergraduate cohorts at the research laboratories and exposing NEESreu students to more diverse research topics and peers.
